title: Perspectives in Biochemical Sciences
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course presents the latest developments and advancements in biochemical sciences as well as the current topics in the society. It aims to alert students the trends and recent breakthrough in biochemistry in medical research. Issues such as stem cell research and infectious diseases shall be examined in this course.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:  1) Demonstrate a broad understanding of biochemical and molecular approaches in life sciences with impacts to our society.  2) Demonstrate a deep understanding of at least one area of contemporary biochemical research.  3) Critically evaluate contemporary research literature and research programs.   4) Support a high-level biochemical research program.  5) Master communication skills in presenting the research findings through effective oral and written presentations.
syllabus: -   Gene editing and therapy-   Recent Advances in the Pathogenesis and Treatment of Influenza Virus-   Apoptosis and Anti-cancer Drug Development -   Biochemistry and Infections-   Biochemical basis of wilderness medicine-   Cancer and Photodynamic Therapy-   Diseases and protein therapeutics-   Stem cells and regenerative medicine-   Protein structures and drug discovery-   Structural biology of protein kinases in drug discovery-   Mitochondrial dysfunction in neurodegenerative diseases-   Nutrition and functional neurochemistry

instructors:
Dr. LO Fai Hang, 

Dr. SIOW Lam, 

Professor AU Wing Ngor Shannon, 

Professor CHOW Hei Man, 

Professor FONG Wing Ping, 

Professor KWAN Kin Ming, 

Professor NGO Chi Ki Jacky, 

Professor SHAW Pang Chui, 

Professor WONG Kam Bo

title: Biochemical Techniques of Forensic Analysis
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course aims at introducing various biochemical principles and techniques for forensic analysis to the students. Students will learn how to observe, collect, analyze and evaluate evidence found at crime scenes. The first part addresses the identification of biological fluids such as blood, semen, and saliva from crime scene. The emphasis will be on the biochemical technologies used in the presumptive and confirmatory tests. The second part of the lecture covers collection and processing of biological samples from crime scenes, DNA analysis using RFLP and PCR-STR typing methods, interpretation of DNA typing results, and court presentation of such biological evidence. Mitochondrial DNA typing and Y chromosome DNA typing will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Exhibit a knowledge base in genetics at the molecular level. 2) Demonstrate the knowledge of common and advanced laboratory techniques in molecular biology. 3) Understand and apply the principles and techniques of molecular biology. 4) Master communication skills in presenting the research findings through effective oral and written presentations. 5) Demonstrate a commitment to professional integrity and ethical behavior consistent with the missions of the university and accepted standards of professional conduct.
syllabus: Introduction to Forensic Sciences - Forensic Serology & Blood Analysis- Detection of Saliva, Semen & Other Bodily Fluids- Forensic Toxicology & ….- Forensic Science & Biological Evidence- Identity Testing, DNA Extraction & Quantitation- Forensic genetics and RFLP Typing- PCR-based STR Profiling & Others- Forensic Issues & Quality Requirements for DNA Testing- Y Chromosome Testing, Mitochondrial DNA Sequencing & Result Interpretation- Reporting, Case Studies & Court Testimony- Current Approaches to Authenticate Chinese Medicinal Material

instructors:
Dr. LAM Yiu Man, 

Mr. TSUI Hong Teng, 

Professor LAU Kwok Fai, 

Professor SHAW Pang Chui

title: Molecular Biology and Genome Science
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course is designed to acquaint students with the field of molecular biology and genome science. The course covers the principles of genetics at the molecular level, physical and biochemical nature of hereditary materials, molecular mechanisms of DNA replication, mutation, and repair, and molecular basis of genetic disorders and their diagnosis. Additionally, the basic recombinant DNA technology, genome editing, contemporary applications of biochemical technology in DNA sequencing and genome mapping, RNA biology and technology, drug discovery and development will be introduced. Contemporary application of computing skills and tools in data analysis for biochemical/biomedical studies will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Demonstrate knowledge and comprehension of core concepts, which includes but is not limited to recombinant DNA technology, mammalian cell culture, protein expression and purification, and antibody engineering. 2) Demonstrate knowledge of ethical principles regarding the use of biotechnology. 3) Demonstrate the ability to understand, analyze and evaluate original research literature and to communicate this understanding using appropriate technology.
syllabus: - Physical and biochemical nature of hereditary materials- Principles of genetics- Replication, mutation and repair of DNA- Genetic Disorders- Inherited metabolic diseases and their diagnosis- Therapeutics for genetic disorders- RNA Biology and Technology- CRISPR Functions and Applications- DNA Sequencing- DNA Sequencing and Application- Gene Tree Construction and Basic Comparative Genomics

instructors:
Professor CHAN Ting Fung Philos, 

Professor NGO Chi Ki Jacky

title: Biochemical and Biomedical Technology
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course aims at introducing recent technologies for biochemical and biomedical analysis. It covers tools and techniques for protein analyses. Modern approaches to identify and characterize protein-protein interaction will be introduced. Moreover, bioengineering of proteins such as enzymes which are of medical and industrial importance will be illustrated. The application of x-ray crystallography in protein structural studies will also be introduced. The course also covers the contemporary applications of biochemical technology in mammalian cell culture technology, stem cell biology and CAR-T cells biotechnology.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Demonstrate knowledge and comprehension of core concepts, which includes but is not limited to structure of the human genome, pharmacogenomics, drug discovery and diagnostics, and softwares and databases used in Bioinformatics. 2) Demonstrate knowledge of ethical principles regarding the use of biotechnology. 3) Demonstrate the ability to understand, analyze and evaluate original research literature and to communicate this understanding using appropriate technology.
syllabus: Mammalian Cell Culture Technology Stem Cell Biology and Application of Stem Cells Protein Structure and Functions Protein-Protein interactions – methods and applications Modern methods in metabolic science Transgenic technology and its application Thermostable Proteins and Enzyme Technology Principles in Protein Crystallography

instructors:
Dr. LEE Ming Ming Marianne, 

Professor AU Wing Ngor Shannon, 

Professor CHOW Hei Man, 

Professor FONG Wing Ping, 

Professor KWAN Kin Ming, 

Professor LAU Kwok Fai, 

Professor TSANG Suk Ying

title: Biochemistry of Food Safety & Environmental Health
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course is concerned with the biochemical impacts in food and environment as they relate to the health of public. The first part introduces the key concepts and principles of food safety and toxicology. The nature and properties of the toxic substances in foods will be covered. Additionally, the impacts of nutrient deficiency to human health will be discussed. The second part addresses issues related to environmental health such as water management, sewage management and treatment, and pollution from hazardous biochemicals and chemicals.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Identify current biochemical impacts in our environment and food.  2) Review the literature and give reports on biochemical approaches to different area which includes but is not limited to infectious disease, pollution from hazardous biochemicals, and food additives. 3) Analyze case studies of public health issues (e.g., toxins associated with foods), biochemical impacts in pest control, water management, sewage management and treatment, etc.). 4) Demonstrate the ability to understand, analyze and evaluate original research literature and to communicate this understanding using appropriate technology.
syllabus: Introduction to Food Toxicology and Health Risk Management  Natural Toxins  Metal Intoxication  Pesticides and Trace Organics  Food Additives and Novel Foods  Food Adulteration and Current Issues  Nutrition & Health I – Nutrient Deficiency  Nutrition & Health II – Chronic Disease Development  Introduction to Biochemistry of Toxic Natural Products and Chemicals  Toxicant Processing in vivo  Diagnosis, Treatment and Prevention of Toxicity  Environmental Health Water Management

instructors:
Dr. LI Yuk Man, 

Professor KWAN Kin Ming, 

Professor NGO Chi Ki Jacky

title: Clinical Biochemistry and Diseases
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci; For students in MSc Biomedical Engineering
description: This course provides students with an introduction to the normal pathways of carbohydrate, lipid, nucleotide and amino acid metabolism. The course will outline the biochemical mechanisms for controlling these pathways under different physiological and nutritional conditions and discuss the importance of diseases arising from defects in these pathways. Particular emphasis will be placed on the biochemical mechanisms concerning the etiology, symptoms and treatment of diseases such as diabetes mellitus, atherosclerosis and other lipid disorders, inborn errors of carbohydrates and amino acid metabolism. Also, how biochemical test results are utilized for the diagnosis and monitoring of diseases are described.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Explain the biochemical mechanisms and pathophysiological processes of common biochemical diseases and disorders. 2) Explain the rationale and theoretical basis for methods used in the diagnosis and monitoring of common biochemical diseases. 3) Analyze biochemical results and suggest the likely pathological etiology, and identify testing where appropriate. 4) Demonstrate the ability to understand, analyze and evaluate original research literature and to communicate this understanding using appropriate technology.
syllabus: Carbohydrate metabolism with clinical correlations Lipid metabolism with clinical correlations Amino acid metabolism with clinical correlations Nucleic Acids Metabolism and Gout Formation Cardiac Health and Diseases Vascular Homeostasis and Diseases Hematologic Function and Diseases  Neurodiseases Clinical Chemistry

instructors:
Dr. NGAI Hung Kui, 

Professor LAU Kwok Fai, 

Professor WONG Chun Kwok, 

Professor WONG Wing Tak Jack

title: Methods in Biochemistry
requirements:
For students in MSc Biochemical and Biomedical Sciences or MSc Biomedical Engineering
Not for students who have taken LSCI5462
description: This course will allow students to gain theoretical and practical, hands-on knowledge of various advanced research methodologies and their applications in biochemical research and pre-clinical services. Methods include: • Ion exchange chromatography • Spectrophotometry • SDS-Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis • Enzymatic assay • DNA cloning technologies and DNA electrophoresis • PCR and site-directed mutagenesis • Bacterial transformation and culture • Recombinant protein expression and purification • Human cell culture and cytotoxicity assay • Fluorescence technology: and flow cytometry, confocal microscopy, fluorescence spectrum scanning and measurement
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) Describe the concepts of modern analytical and instrumental techniques relevant to measurements in biochemical research and pre-clinical services.  2) Master a number of biochemical techniques such as polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and Western blot analysis, enzymatic assay, DNA electrophoresis and DNA fingerprinting , PCR and polymorphism analysis, human cell culture and cytotoxicity assay, ELISA and flow cytometry, Rasmol and computer tools for analysis, Bacterial transformation and test for food contamination, statistical analysis of toxic chemicals in environment and fermentation technology. 3) Justify the selection of different bio-analytical methods to characterize the composition of a complex sample. 4) Critically evaluate the merits, limitations and future trends of various biochemical analytical techniques. 5) Work in a collaborative manner with others on a team, contributing to the management, planning and implementation of a task. 6) Demonstrate a commitment to professional integrity and ethical behavior consistent with the missions of the university and accepted standards of professional conduct.
syllabus: Chromatography Electrophoresis Proteomics DNA Cloning Techniques Recombinant Proteins Cell culture, cytotoxicity assays Fluorescence and Microscopy  Flow Cytometry

instructors:
Dr. LEONG Lok I, 

Dr. LO Fai Hang, 

Professor WONG Kam Bo

title: MSc Project
requirements: For students in MSc Biochem & Biomedical Sci
description: Students will be required to do a project or a literature survey and/or a mini research on a current topic in biochemistry or biomedical sciences under the supervision of a teaching staff of Department of Biochemistry.

title: Management and Accreditation of Biochemical Laboratory
requirements:
For students in MSc Biochemical and Biomedical Sciences or MSc Biomedical Engineering
Not for students who have taken LSCI5463
description: The aims of this course are to introduce basic concepts and adequate skills of laboratory management, safety and quality assurance in biochemical laboratories. Special topics such as biochemical testing and manufacturing process, good laboratory practice, laboratory accreditation, genetic testing and experimental protocols and method validation ect, will be discussed.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should: 1) Be knowledgeable in the areas of intellectual property, license, patent and accreditation system. 2) Be able to understand the basic concepts and adequate skills of laboratory management. 3) Be able to understand the basic concepts and adequate skills of laboratory management. 4) Be able to execute safety and quality assurance protocols in biochemical laboratories according to standards.  5) Be able to perform biochemical testing and manufacturing process, good laboratory and manufacturing practice, laboratory accreditation, genetic testing and method validation etc.
syllabus: Accreditation Program of AAALAC International for Care and Use of Laboratory Animals Clinical Laboratory Sciences and Practice Quality Assurance in Clinical Laboratory Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) Intellectual Property Rights Relevant to Biotechnology Enforcement of IPRs, Agreement Basics and Licensing Preparation for Establishing a Biotech Start-up Management of R&D: from People to Lab Management of R&D: from Lab to Portfolio Establishment and Management of a Biotech Start-up

instructors:
Dr WONG Yuen Ting, 

Dr. CHOI Pui Wah, 

Dr. YEUNG Hiu Yan, 

Dr. YEUNG Shu Ying, 

Professor CHO Chi Shing, 

Professor LAU Kwok Fai, 

Professor LEE Chi Ming

title: Research Methods and Literature Review in Biochemical and Biomedical Sciences
requirements: For students in MSc Biochemical and Biomedical Sciences
description: This course aims at providing students in the MSc programme with the essential concepts of basic research methods, project management, scientific writing and presentation skills, statistical analysis of data and academic honesty in the field of biochemical and biomedical sciences. Students must submit a literature review or a research proposal for examination by the end of the course.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: • Have an in-depth knowledge in scientific method and research management;  • Develop competencies in finding, reading and critically evaluating relevant scientific literature;  • Acquire skills in information searching, scientific writing and oral communication;  • Master generic skills such as critical thinking, team building and lifelong learning techniques;  • Understand the basic statistical concepts and perform statistical analysis of biological data;  • Learn the importance of academic honesty.
syllabus: Start a Scientific Project Using ‘Scientific Method’ How to Write a Scientific Document and an M.Sc. Thesis Scientific Conduct and Ethical Issues Basic Statistics for Handling Experimental Data

title: MSc Research Project
requirements:
For students in MSc Biochemical and Biomedical Sciences
Prerequisite: BBMS6500
description: Students will be required to do a research project on a current topic in biochemistry or biomedical sciences under the supervision of a teaching staff of School of Life Sciences. Students must submit an MSc thesis for examination by the end of the course.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to: • Have in-depth knowledge and skills in scientific method and research process;  • Develop competencies in finding, reading and critically evaluating relevant scientific literature;  • Execute experiments and analyze data carefully;  • Perform statistical analysis of data with good interpretation and discussion;  • Master generic skills such as critical thinking, team building and lifelong learning techniques;  • Understand the importance of academic honesty.
syllabus: Introduction for Research-type M.Sc. Project Rules and Safety in Research Labs Conduct a research project on a current biochemistry or biomedical science topic under supervision
